online.game
Class RBoard<CELLTYPE extends cell<CELLTYPE>>

java.lang.Object
  online.game.BaseBoard
      online.game.RBoard<CELLTYPE>
Type Parameters:
CELLTYPE -
All Implemented Interfaces:
PlayConstants, Digestable
Direct Known Subclasses:
gBoard
public abstract class RBoard<CELLTYPE extends cell<CELLTYPE>>
extends BaseBoard

a board where the cells have random locations, not in a regular grid. Cells can be accessed through the allCells chain, or getCellArray()

Author:
ddyer

getCell

public CELLTYPE getCell(CELLTYPE c)
get the cell from the current board which shares the same role as c, which is most likely from a different board of the same game. This is used in copying boards.

Parameters:
c -
Returns:
the local cell with the same role as C

unlinkCell

public void unlinkCell(CELLTYPE C)
unlink this cell bidirectionally, effectively removing it from the board. this is used to create holes in the board, like the center square in tzaar This also removes C from "allCells", but not from the cell array

Parameters:
C -

sameboard

public void sameboard(RBoard<CELLTYPE> from_b)
verify a copy of this board. This method checks the cells on the board using sameCell. This method is typically wrapped by each subclass to check other state in the board.

Parameters:
from_b -

closestCell

public CELLTYPE closestCell(int x,
                            int y,
                            java.awt.Rectangle brect)
find the closest cell on the board. For many cases, this is preferable to checking each cell for closeness to the mouse, because there are no gape or overlaps in the result.

Parameters:
x - the x location
y - the Y location
brect -
Returns:
a cell

Parameters:

public abstract int cellToY(CELLTYPE c)
get the y coordinate associated with the cell

Parameters:
c - cell on the board

closestCell

public CELLTYPE closestCell(int x,
                            int y)
find the closest cell to a given x,y. This is used to determine what the mouse is pointing at without leaving any gaps between cells. If the mouse is not "near" any cell, return null. This isn't quite enough for torroidal boards that wrap around.

Parameters:
x -
y -
Returns:
a cell

SetDisplayRectangle

public void SetDisplayRectangle(java.awt.Rectangle r)
adjust the internal scaling parameters so the board displays inside the specified rectangle. This works by running a trial transformation of all the points on the board, then scaling the result to completely fill the rectangle if possible.

Parameters:
r -
